title: What will be the closing price per barrel for West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil on 13 May 2020, according to Bloomberg?
preds: Already above $25/barrel. Technical analysis pointing to buy momentum.
I used the returns distribution of the June contracts in 2020, taking into account the time left before the closing.
The market closed at $25.34.  In about an hour, electronic trading will start. Again, I'm not sure about the rationale for the 3 AM deadline for forecasts.

This is so annoyingly close. The day trading will close in 15 min and the price is at $25.33, down 30+ cents in the last 20-25 min. By the way, if this forecast will be decided on the closing price, why wait until 3 AM on Wednesday?
time to re-balance. The market seems to be reacting positively to Saudi announcement of additional 1 MMBD cut in June. Most of today, oil traded above $25/bbl.
WTI is nearing $26 now, so overweighting $25-35.

I am not sure the best way to forecast this when it is hovering so close to the boundary of two options. Revising my forecast of below $25 down significantly to account for the movement above $25 and also Saudi Arabia’s announcement that they will cut production by a further 1 million barrels per day in June.
The movement today has been almost all above $25. Moving more into that bucket.
One day left, ... unless you can predict what will happen tomorrow, it's a coin toss.
Oilprice dot com charting at $25.52 as of this posting.  Bloomberg charting (via Nymex) at $25.53

As on today (12 May), it is trading at 25.50 and the forecast for the next week is towards up for the June contract. With 18 days to exercise the June contract, it is expected upswing by 5%. Hence, in my estimate, the closing price will be above $25 and below $35.

This looks like it will be very close, based on how the price has been bouncing around above and below $25 since late last week. Putting slightly more on above $25, due to the up/down volatility. There doesn't seem to be much optimism, though, regarding continued increases [1,2]. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/11/oil-markets-coronavirus-crude-output-in-focus.html
[2] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-pulls-back-on-concerns-over-potential-second-wave-of-coronavirus-infections-2020-05-11

The market struggled to break $25 but failed. However, Saudis announced another 1 MMBD of production cut in June. If the market responds to these news on Tuesday, I'll shift more towards $25+. [As a footnote, I must say that the question is a bit misleading because May 13 price of June futures contract is not a true reflection of physical prices in mid-May but that is the Bloomberg reference].
Been hovering around $25 the past week or so
Oil markets remained choppy. The price of Brent crude rose above $30 a barrel for the first time in weeks.
2 counter currents. Saudis agreed to cut a million more barrels a day but fear of second coronavirus raising its head.

Unless you are an insider, for example an oil trader, it's very difficult to predict what will happen in the next two days.  Longer term, you can base an educated guess on what you read in the financial news.  Even so, there are many unknowns.  Short term, it's a crap shoot.

I am over exposed low, so am overcompensating high.  The EIA report will be out tomorrow, so the author of this question chose a difficult date - there will be a lot of volatility tomorrow.    My expectation is that demand is starting to come back, and that the change in the oil inventories will be small.    Generally this is positive for supporting price.  Gasoline demand is ramping up rapidly, in the US.    In the next couple of weeks look for refineries to start to increase their run rates.  Much like a top teetering, or a hurricane stalled, the market could sway either way.
Saudis announced an additional cut because their budget is ok, therefore here is my third forecast of the day

current daily price at 23.5-24.0. At 24h from closing, there is little external hazard to consider in the sense that the chances are really thin (is this right?). So let's assume daily variability over the last few days and project that for tomorrow to get the chances in the 25$+ bucket.

With 3 more days to go any +30% swing still lands within the <$35 range With more countries opening up, demand is slowly opening up - The Financial markets are surprisingly bullish for a few weeks now and my expectation is that that goes unchanged at least within this week (as opening up measures will show promise, but the adverse news of slow pick-up or new CoV cases not yet in news cycle
Likely on the bubble ........5 days to count down, place your bets.

All day, the market struggled to go up but trading has been within a narrow range, annoyingly just under $25/bbl. The fundamentals still exert downward pressure but any given day, prices may be over $25. Still, only willing to change my forecasts by 10%. Tomorrow is another day in this crazy market.

Crude Oil & Natural Gas
CL1:COM
WTI Crude Oil (Nymex)
USD/bbl.	24.63
Sitting at 23.99 from May 4th. The last time it was above 25 was in March. Based on that trend, sticking with the current rate.
The market tried to push up but ended up closing down at about $23.50. Fundamentals still favor the downside unless we get some major news on demand recovery. Hence the 10% for >$25.
Small adjustment.  With less than one week to go it's close to a toss up.
Still a glut of oil in the world

The war between OPEC and Russia is still worsenning.
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CL1:COM
The trend over the past 9-10 days says it will be over $25.  But the weak economy indicates that the price has further to fall.  It's pretty much a coin toss.
Likely to be on the bubble, but I was in the first bucket for a long time, and now need to frantically back pedal.
I'm over exposed low, over compensating high

This is essentially talking about the WTI June contract, which expires on 19th of May. Currently trading at 26.33 USD/barrel - but there could be pressure on the near month contract as expiry draws near AND most of the ETF and other Index based funds have already moved to far month contracts (e.g. USO).

There is till a massive fleet of cargoes  offshore, the stocks are at their maximum and still prices spike. The Saudis are on it, but how long their price support will last is still uncertain, I stay like that for now.

strike=25: 0.74
strike=35: 0.96
strike=45: 1.00

The market seems to be losing its optimism from first two days of the week. Below $25 but by only a dollar.  There is a lot of technical trading.  Storage numbers to be released later in the week, news about OPEC++ cuts, and demand recovery can move the market up or down in a big way. Still think fundamentals are towards the downside.

Today the price is fluctuating both above and below $25.  With one week to go it looks like it could end up on either side of $25.  But it seems less likely to continue increasing.  It's more likely to crash again on continuing bad COVID news.
Changing my forecast massively since I did not see the rally coming up at all.
price is above $25 now and trending up
It's on the rise (five days in a row).

The futures market seems to think that oil demand and supply is re-balancing: June prices rose several days in a row, ending above $25 today. But, the physical fundamentals are too uncertain to shift too much weight at this time. A piece of news (say, Russia cheating on its OPEC+ cuts) could turn things around as quickly. Tomorrow is another day.
Price may be heading higher on signs of increased demand, lowering excess supply. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-04/oil-extends-gains-above-20-as-output-curbs-ease-glut-concerns

Yikes Volatility with a captial V. A week to go and the market suddenly reversed, perhaps temporarily but it only has to hold for a day, at the close to count. I am so glad to be making this bet here and not in the open market.

THis just got more interesting. Imagine the Control Room in cushing at the Pipe Plex. Your board is showing you that you have new line capacity and someone has done the math to know what is the most efficient storage capacity cap that will allow the line diverters to work properly and routinely.  When they are at peak possible efficiency we'll see the price settle. “It gives a message to the overall market that everyone is leaning in,” Reid Morrison, global energy advisory leader for PwC, said in a phone interview.
However, the rebound will likely be a brief reprieve, according to Harry Tchilinguirian, head of commodity markets strategy at BNP Paribas SA, as the market’s supply overhang eclipses the size of planned productions cuts. “There is a lot of upward momentum in supply that needs to be reversed,” 
also - https://gcaptain.com/oil-rallies-as-u-s-crude-build-seen-slowing/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Gcaptain+%28gCaptain.com%29&goal=0_f50174ef03-3c3310dd52-170102337&mc_cid=3c3310dd52&mc_eid=c74873c672
Price has doubled in last seven days. Turning the wheel pretty hard here.
Oil restriction is in place and most of europe is deconfining globally making room into the storage facilities...

Most are predicting prices moving lower.  I think oil is on an uptick, interrupted by volatility and has good chances to close above 25.   I am over exposed <25 (100)  I think the chance is 80% under $25 so I'm compensating.
Needs to increase by 3.83 (18%) to be above $25.00. This is a lot more likely than my previous forecast of 0%!
After a tumultuose week or two for oil, I can't see it getting back above 25 with excess production likely to happen.

Who is going to buy the oil that is already in the market?
Not me, I can tell you that. This is like when a kid asks to get McDonalds and mom says, "no, we have food at home."
May as well go all the way in on under $25, not that much time left, things are still up in the air regarding demand for oil.
Futures markets currently pricing WTI @ ≤ $25 through August 2020.  Some meaningful possibility of a big bump if there is very unexpected good economic news and/or irrational exuberance.
Still no sign of an upward movement in futures trading as May starts with the promised OPEC+ production cuts.  Everyone is watching to see who might cheat (Russia, SA, etc).

some countries are starting to reopen, which increases demand, and alleviates storage issues
no futures closing contract that month

It's extremely implausible that oil will trade above $25 on May 13th. If anything, it's likelier to be lower than today. Storage is quickly filling up (supply flows still greatly exceed demand flows), with maximum capacity only weeks away.  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/25/scary-visceral-unprecedented-traders-describe-oils-wild-week-and-fall-to-negative-prices.html
Will be too soon for consumption to have risen enough to push prices back up
JUN20 contract -44% today to $11.15 at time of writing.
Production exceeds demand by far, no reason to believe that will change in the next 3 weeks.

Today's plunge shows the depth of the storage capacity problem.  The negative prices only apply to May futures, and June futures remain slightly more normalized; however, if the pandemic continues next month's futures may be heavily affected as well.

It would be a mistake to view today's headline price action that WTI will certainly be <$25 3 weeks from now. June contract (the active contract on 5/13) is still $21. With inventories unlikely to be drawn down significantly over the next month, it must mean the market expects significant rightsizing of production which is hard to reverse once it happens meaning any positive demand side surprise would give WTI a big boost.

While May contract is at -38. The June is trading 21.

$-3.7 per barrel. This has never happened before.

There are signs of weakness everywhere. Buyers in Texas are offering as little as $2 a barrel for some oil streams, raising the possibility that producers may soon have to pay to have crude taken off their hands.” Ok🥳🥳, partytime.
Oil just went to $0.10 a barrel. WOW.
FWIW: WTI market reportedly in 'contango' right now. (Later futures prices are higher than those that expire earlier.) https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/20/business/stock-market-today-coronavirus.html
Hate to react to short-term price movements ($11 as I write) but this time around, the market reaction seems consistent with the unprecedented conditions in today's oil market.

Demand is dead, storage is filling rapidly, and there are less than four weeks left in the challenge.  So I'm overweighting <$25 per barrel.

At this point, the only reason I'm leaving 15% for >$25 is the market's tendency to react to news. There are some such as TX RRC supply management. Although they all seem fundamentally weak, one cannot rule out market's overreaction (such as prices going up with anticipation of OPEC+ meeting last week).
bumping top bracket. WTI down to circa $20 and not seeming like it's going anywhere in a big hurry.

All in until there's any sign of an increase.
Futures pricing lags but is trending lower.
After reading comments putting more in bin 1. Bin 2 is possible if an announcement of impending increase in economic activity is announced.

A lot of hype on the recent 10 mb/d cuts, created an artificial & speculative boost to prices, which could not and did not last.  EIA reported an inventory build of 19 mllion barrels in the US.  Inventory is building so fast they are reversing the gulf coast pipeline to deliver oil TO cushing, allowing the 76 million open barrels of space to be used there.  Gas inventories up 5 million barrels, despite refiner run rates declinging to 12.6 mbd (from 14.9).    Expect gas prices to continue to fall, and refiners to cut run rates more strenuously.  Texas Railroad board is discussing cuts of 1mb/d. Point of all this -- is the cuts discussed are no where near the ***35*** mb/d of demand destruction. 
The cuts do serve a useful purpose in spreading the pain out in a structured way.   And, if we're lucky, they will extend the amount of time before all the storage is full.    All the usual commercial storage (strategic reserve, cushing,) will be fully mid june-ish.  All the weird unconventional storage mid july ish (railroad tankers, panamax carriers, fuel storage at airports, home heating oil) by Aug 1.  Oil starts running out on the ground mid august... https://finance.yahoo.com/news/oil-prices-sink-record-breaking-150000620.html
Higher prices unlikely, as OPEC will increase production in these cases. Lower cases would result if containment efforts do not realize as expected

Markets are digesting the historic OPEC++ deal and are even less impressed today than they were yesterday.  Fundamentals remain the same: demand destruction is much larger than the promised cuts (twice as much according to some estimates), upstream CAPEX reduction impacts will not be felt in production within a month, storage is filling fast.  to top it all, Saudis reduced their OSP by >$3/bbl.

Trending down - another 2.00 to 20.9 in the last 24 hours...
Reducing >25 to 20%

April 14 = $21.15USD/bbl
Short term looks like $25 is the ceiling not the floor. Recovery to price won't happen in 30 days, maybe not even in 3 months. Small drillers closing up shop. Big drillers cutting capex and exploration like never before. My car has not been out of the garage in 10 days.

Latest agreements were already considered by the markets which lead to the cautious reaction in price development we can observe currently. For the short and mid-term I do not expect a relevant increase in price level as no major increase in demand is to be expected against the background of CORONA pandemic and worldwide stock levels are high at the same time.

April 14.- WTI22.58(^+0.17) Since last entry (Mar19), almost a month ago, the price seems to have found an equilibrium point around 24.50 (+28.34, -20.09).  Goldman Sachs does not expect oil prices to rise anytime soon. (https://oilprice.com/Energy/Oil-Prices/Goldman-Sachs-Dont-Expect-Oil-Prices-To-Rise-On-Historic-Oil-Deal.html )  OPEC+ deal ends Saudi Arabia vs Russia conflict. OPEC+ agree to drop 9.7m till 2022. Deal not enough to counter steep price fall. Goldman Sachs sticks with WTI Crude $20 dollar forecast. ( https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/13/business/dealbook/oil-price-opec-deal.html )  1Month to go. Not good changes of going above 25. COVID around the world keeps being an unknown, that is not good to keep speculators at bay. Uncertain everyone will keep bellow de 9.7 bpd mark. besides the mark is not even close to counter surplus stock deplete and make de commodity scarcer. Anything above $35 seems impossible to my untrained oil logic.

April 13 = $23/bbl range for the day. OPEC has made their move, but, it will take weeks to come into effect. And the agreed to cut doesn't equal the shortfall in demand or so Mr. Market believes. We have 30 days to adjust. Looks like a painful 30 days for those pumping.

After a weekend of calls, Mexico is on board w OPEC+ cuts (sort of) but markets are not impressed. CME May futures is <$23/bbl.  Traders probably look at global storage of all kind: underground, above ground, pipelines, floating. At the current rate of excess S, storage will be full within a month. 10 MBD cut is not nearly enough.  Trump tweeting 20 MBD. There will be other OPEC+ meetings and heavy phone traffic in coming days. Until we see the results of those calls, I re-increased the probability of <$25.

Shack-whacky update:
Current price: 22.9, down from 26 over the weekend despite OPEC's decision.
52-week range 19.27 to 64.39.
30 days to go.
Currently, oil consumption is 34% less than usual.
The US accounts for approx. 20% of global production and consumption.
What is the probable level of consumption in 30 days? Say 20-30% below usual.
Can we anticipate a structural change in consumption throughout the year and maybe beyond? Say 50%.
Will storage capacity be maxed out? Probably.
What is the next-lowest operational cost of production at 80% usual level? Dunno.
Is the futures market leading or lagging? My guess is it's lagging.
Lowering my forecast ...

So there is a agreement to Cut, but one reached when no one had anywhere left to put the production, so the question will turn on who breaks the agreement first and when. I think it takes til August to return the production  back on.

Trump has pledged production cuts, in line with OPEC countries and Mexico, to start in May. This alters the supply and demand paradigm. 10% (what OPEC have agreed), shouldn’t be enough to increase price back to pre Covid but should see it increase a little.

The price war’s onset sent the oil markets careening into a high degree of volatility, but future prices should rise back to a more normal level once the current set of negotiation disagreements are resolved and Trump’s brokered truce between SA and Russia moves forward.  If Putin’s short-term goal was to decimate American competitors, he achieved it; however, shale drilling (due to a front-end spike in initial production curves and high fixed costs) is typically dormant in an adverse price environment and can be quickly ramped up again once prices rise.  American producers won’t stay down for long, and should soon be able to introduce more competitiveness to the market that will drive prices closer towards equilibrium.  It’s merely a question of how much progress can be made before mid-May.

OPEC+ announced a 2-month, 10 MBD cut, CME May futures price, which was going higher with anticipation before the announcement, fell following the announcement (near $23). Still, with many ifs (Mexico ratifying agreement, producers actually delivering the cuts, some of the upstream cuts yielding production reduction sooner than expected, unusual storage (floating, pipelines, etc) come to the rescue, and, the biggie, demand recovers sooner), the chances of a price above $25 has slightly improved.
Demand will still be low. Production cut will drive up some but there is still a glut. Sauds and Russia and Opec will cut 10 million barrels a day. US and Mexico will cut.
OPEC+ meeting yesterday means it seems like price will be capped for at least the short term.

Back to fence sitting as the pumpers try to find places for their oil. We have 23 days to find homes for the pumped crude. For the next 2 weeks or so oil may be really cheap, then slowly stabilize. Or not. OPEC and Russia agree to cut about 10M bbl/day in production - STARTING in May. @cdob63 offers a more conservative view of the situation.

What can change in five weeks?
Five weeks ago, March 5, my world was 'normal' and WTI was 46.90. The concepts 'peak oil', fracking and bitumen sands were normal though debatable.
In five weeks the Saudi-Russia-US-Venezuela games may be over and the players may be looking at full tanks but no appetite for fire-sale pricing, i,e., 25-35, or just enough to restrict fracking.
People may be returning to their routines (10%: 35-45). Or there may be food insecurity, economic tailspin or some other downward impact on price (10%: <25). Not easily predicted!
Stay well! :)

A lot happening on this right now:
- Trump met with senior oil execs on Friday where there was no discussion of mandated cuts to US oil production. Trump is also optimistic that Russia and Saudi Arabia will reach a deal. [0]
- Trump also said he was willing to put tariffs on oil imports to protect American energy jobs [1]
- The OPEC+ meeting that was supposed to happen on Monday 6th, has now been postponed till Thursday 9th because Russia and Saudi Arabia are still fighting over who's fault the plunge in prices is. [2]
- He further reiterated that Saudi Arabia had agreed with Russia to reduce production by 10m bpd (this has not been confirmed by Russia or Saudi [2]
- The International Energy Agency (IEA) said on Friday that even if there were a cut of 10m bpd, it would not be enough to counter the huge fall in demand [3] So to me this all says:
- US are unlikely to mandate production cuts, although there will of course be a natural decline in production from the shale producers
- Russia and Saudi Arabia are struggling to come to a deal of 10m bpd
- Even if they do come to a deal, it doesn't seem likely to make up for the loss of demand so little chance of WTI prices getting back to the $50-$60 dollar range in the short-term. Options market [4] is currently implying the following approx. probabilities: <$25 = 20%
$25-$35 = 40%
$35-$45 = 26%
$45-$55 = 10%
>$55 = 4% I do think this understates the probability of a <$25 outcome and overstates the $35-$45 odds so going to reflect that in my updated forecast. [0] https://edition.cnn.com/2020/04/03/business/oil-ceos-trump-meeting/index.html
[1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil-trump/trump-says-if-he-has-to-put-tariffs-on-oil-imports-to-protect-energy-workers-he-will-idUSKBN21M0V8
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec-saudi-russia/opec-meeting-delayed-as-saudi-arabia-and-russia-row-over-oil-price-collapse-sources-idUSKBN21M0FY
[3] https://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2020/04/05/opec-meeting-delayed-as-saudi-arabia-and-russia-row-over-oil-price-collapse

By executive order the national petroleum reserve in Wyoming has been made available to private industry. That gives them a place to put production and stabilizes the price for a while.

The "Trump bump" is likely more indicative of the US leader's ability to move markets based on what he says and not what may or may not happen. Successfully forecasting the price of oil seems nearly impossible  - even for industry insiders. Given I don’t know much about the oil market I don’t think I’ll fare any better. However, let’s start off by trying to put some crude base rates on what the price of WTI might do. As of close of business 27th March WTI Crude Oil was trading at $21.51 a barrel. There are roughly 1.5 months until the forecast date, which is approximately 31 trading days. Using data from FRED (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DCOILWTICO), we can calculate the historical 1.5 month realised volatility of WTI going back to 1986.  https://pasteboard.co/J1lkszJ.png The average is 14.1%, but as you can see from the graph in the link above it varies massively. There seems to be infrequent but massive spikes in the level of realised volatility. While the long run average 1.5-month volatility of WTI is 14.1%, over the past 12 months it’s actually only been 12.3%! https://pasteboard.co/J1m2ERt.png I expected this to be much much higher, but volatility was actually quite low before the recent Russia/Saudi tiff. Over the past month (after it all kicked off) the 1.5-month realised volatility has unsurprisingly rocketed up to an average of 20.4%. So what should we use for our base rate over the next month-and-a-half? I’m going to naïvely take an average of the 3 averages and assume the volatility of WTI until the forecast date will be 15.6%. Note: This all assumes a normal/Gaussian distribution, which I am well aware, does not translate to the real world. I’m merely using it as a rough guide. So based on the current price of $21.51, a volatility of 15.6% means there should be a 68% chance that oil will end up between $18.16 (21.51 * 0.844) and $24.86. There is a 27% chance the price will move between 1 and 2 standard deviations and end up between 14.80 (21.51 * 0.688) and 18.15 or 24.87 and 28.22 (21.51 * 1.312).  And a 5% chance it will end up outside of that. This does not align neatly with the options given in the question, but we can roughly put the %’s in to get a base case of:
Less than $25.00: 68% +13.5% + 2.5% = 84%
Between $25.00 and $35.00, inclusive: 13.5% (understating it a bit I know) Which leaves only 2.5% for the remaining options, which I’ll allocate in a 3:2:1 format to get: More than $35.00 but less than $45.00: 1.25%
Between $45.00 and $55.00, inclusive: 0.8%
More than $55.00: 0.45% So know that we have a VERY naïve outside view, let’s look at the inside view. The Coronavirus means there is currently a vastly reduced demand for oil. There is also an increased supply due to Russia walking out on OPEC+ and the Saudi’s pumping up their output in retaliation.  At the current price there’s going be a lot of US shale producers that default. But are they going to do so in the next month and a half? Or stop pumping in that timeframe? I’m not sure. Russia will suffer if oil stays at the current price - the ruble has already depreciated 22% this year vs. the dollar and obviously they will get less revenue from the oil they do sell. However, they claim that they can withstand oil prices of $25-30 a barrel for the next 6-10 years and have an oil break-even price of $42 a barrel vs. c.$80 a barrel for Saudi Arabia in terms of their fiscal budgets (https://www.ft.com/content/4009472c-620e-11ea-b3f3-fe4680ea68b5 - sorry, pay wall). So they seem likely to be in this for at least the medium-term. Saudi Arabia needs an oil price of $80/barrel to get to a balanced budget. But they are the ones who started flooding the market with an extra 2.5m barrels a day when Russia walked out on OPEC+ (https://www.ft.com/content/755663c0-62ad-11ea-a6cd-df28cc3c6a68
). I find it difficult to see them relenting before May 13th, albeit I expect either Russia or Saudi will come back to the negotiating table in the medium-term. So given all this info, perhaps I should be adjusting my forecast to put EVEN more weight on the lower prices? Alas, I'm not going to do that. I feel my crude model probably understates the potential volatility of oil over the next while and I feel very uneasy assigning only 13.5% to the $25-35 range. So I've adjusted my final numbers to put more weight on that target price, and a bit more on the tail cases too.

I wrote this article today... Why the Oil Price Crash of 2020 will be short January 2020 brought troubles to the oilfield, a coronavirus known as CoVid-19. Originating in China, it spread faster than flu, and more deadly. To combat it, Chinese authority imposed quarantines, and other social distancing measures. It worked, but the engines of industry ground down and the Chinese economy needed less and less oil. This led to a surplus of 2+ million barrels per day.  Fast forward to March, a worldwide pandemic is underway and economies are slowing down rapidly. IHS Markit believes CoVid-19 will cause 3.8 million barrels spare capacity to hit the markets.  OPEC + has suffered a possible fatal blow, Russia no longer wants to go along with cuts recommend by OPEC led by Saudi Arabia. So the Saudis have ramped up production to 12 million to flood the market and teach Russia a lesson about unity. That now puts 5.8 million surplus barrels into the worlds supply. That is why oil has fallen from $50s down to $27 before it stabilized at $33 at the time of this writing. In a nutshell, this is a show of spite in game theory.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spite_(game_theory)
Saudi and Russia did not agree upon some master strategy to destroy American shale production to regain market share, cripple the global economy for world domination, or part of some scheme by the Illuminati to take control of the UN.  Rather it is just a punitive action against a reticent partner. It occurred after a failed negotiation that gives us a clue to the duration.  Saudi has cash reserves to go 3 years at $33/bbl and make their budget, Russia for even longer. Sure, one could argue they could drain their reserves to teach the other a lesson, but that is not rational behavior by heads of state. Russia just wanted a better deal, the Saudis wanted fairness. They will likely hammer out a palatable comprise within weeks. Rumors have it that negotiations are still happening.  On the other hand, China has shown signs that it’s epidemic has burned out. We expected a normal epidemic curve of 2-3 months up, and 2-3 months down, but if we are to trust Chinese numbers, they suppressed the epidemic curve to just 3 months. There is now an immediate push to jump up the economy, within weeks or months they should be consuming more oil, hopefully taking 1-2 million barrels off the market. That is good news, and better, inevitable. Almost nothing can stop the post-epidemic recovery, for any country. I took a survey of oilfield executives and asked the simple question of “How many months will oil stay below $40/bbl?”  Answers: 2,2,3,5,6,6,9,9,12   Mean: 6  StDev:3.4  68% range: 2.5 to 9.5 months. If a Saudi-Russian reduction agreement happens, oil should at least get to the mid 40s range. Then if China gets back on line, they should drive up oil ~$5/bbl more. It may be up to a year before we hit mid $50 oil, but upper $40s should happen within 3-6 months. @Emil @Anneinak @cdob63 @cmeinel @dlaiocean @Dillyweed @dsarin

Factors softening WTI - 1) price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia, 2) both Russia and Saudi are in the midst of political change (Saudi reforms/Putin legacy), 3) coronavirus softness, 4) economic softening reflected in drop of interest rates, share market drop.

4 reasons: 1) OPEC+ producers can clearly see that the oil demand is going to collapse with the emergence of renewable energy, particularly electric vehicles, so they they don’t want to hold a stranded assets so they’ll sell at any price.  2) Russia and Saudi are obviously cooperating to crush the US shale industry which has a much higher minimum cost of production and a high level of private debt - so once the shale producers fail to generate enough cash flow to service their debts, these producers go under. When Secretary Pompeo was in Eastern Europe earlier in the year and offered to sell them as much oil and gas at a market rate, this probably sparked Russian unease and drove the Russians to seek to push the US out of the fossil fuel energy production. 3) US oil producers have their entire 2020 production hedged out through the year end into the start of 2021. Therefore, any desire to put pressure on these producers by the Saudis and the Russians and OPEC+ means that they have to keep the price low or drive it lower throughout the year. Hence, my confidence in a very low oil forecast. This forecast is also very low because when markets collapse like this they can stay quite low for longer periods than most people expect and they tend to build a base before prices go up again. 4) There exists the outside possibility but worth noting because of its strategic importance that US oil producers are cooperating with the Russians and the Saudis based on their mutual desire to push oil prices so low that it upends the world movement to renewable energy and puts the electric car industry out of business. It could simply be their overarching objective through the year 2021 that they all will lower oil prices to the floor and keep their consumers using oil in all things and forget about carbon taxes, renewable energy, and non-internal combustion engine powered vehicles.
